quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 5 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 5.8: Ethers Reactions
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Acidic cleavage of ethers and epoxide ring-opening

questions.question: Which of the following reagents is strong enough to cleave the $C-O$ bond in a simple ether?
questions.explanation: Ethers are relatively inert but can be cleaved by strong nucleophilic acids ($HI$ or $HBr$). The acid protonates the oxygen, making it a better leaving group for the halide ion to attack.

questions.question: When one mole of diethyl ether reacts with one mole of cold, concentrated $HI$, what are the products?
questions.explanation: In cold conditions with limited acid, the ether is cleaved once to produce one molecule of alcohol and one molecule of alkyl halide.

questions.question: What happens if an ether is heated with an excess of concentrated $HI$?
options: The initial alcohol formed is further converted into an alkyl iodide
The reaction stops after forming an alcohol
The ether is oxidized to a carboxylic acid
questions.explanation: Excess acid will react with the intermediate alcohol to form a second mole of alkyl halide. The net reaction is $R-O-R + 2HI \rightarrow 2R-I + H_2O$.

questions.question: In the cleavage of an unsymmetrical ether ($R-O-R'$) involving a primary and a secondary group via an $S_N2$ mechanism, where does the halide ion attack?
questions.explanation: Under $S_N2$ conditions, the halide nucleophile prefers the less sterically hindered carbon atom.

questions.question: What makes epoxides (oxiranes) significantly more reactive than regular ethers?
options: Ring strain in the three-membered ring
The oxygen atom is more electronegative in a ring
questions.explanation: The bond angles in a three-membered ring are approx $60^{\circ}$, far from the ideal $109.5^{\circ}$. This 'ring strain' makes epoxides very eager to undergo ring-opening reactions.

questions.question: What is the product of the acid-catalyzed ring-opening of ethylene oxide with water?
questions.explanation: Acid-catalyzed hydration of an epoxide opens the ring to form a vicinal diol (a glycol).

questions.question: When a Grignard reagent ($R-MgX$) reacts with ethylene oxide followed by acid workup, the product is:
options: A primary alcohol with two additional carbons
A secondary alcohol with one additional carbon
questions.explanation: The nucleophilic $R$ group attacks one of the carbons of the epoxide, opening the ring. This adds a $-CH_2CH_2OH$ unit to the $R$ group.

questions.question: In the base-catalyzed ring-opening of an unsymmetrical epoxide, which carbon does the nucleophile attack?
options: The nucleophile does not attack epoxides in base
questions.explanation: In basic conditions (where steric hindrance dominates), the nucleophile attacks the least hindered carbon ($S_N2$ behavior).

questions.question: Which of the following describes the stereochemistry of epoxide ring-opening?
options: Anti-addition (the nucleophile and the OH end up trans)
Syn-addition (the nucleophile and the OH end up cis)
Retention of configuration at both carbons
questions.explanation: Because the nucleophile attacks from the back side of the $C-O$ bond, the resulting groups are positioned 'anti' to each other.

questions.question: Ethylene oxide is industrially important as a precursor to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Ethylene oxide is the starting material for ethylene glycol, used in antifreeze and in the production of PET plastics (polyester).

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've mastered the tricky chemistry of ether cleavage and epoxides.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You understand the importance of ring strain in epoxide reactivity.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Remember the difference between acid and base-catalyzed epoxide opening.
scoreMessages.0: Review the $S_N2$ mechanism as it applies to ether cleavage.
